p: Representative locomotion tracking pattern ( Figure 4A) illustrates the differences in the exploration of the familiar object (F) and the novel object (N) within the NOR. In the NOR test, one-way ANOVA revealed significant effect of treatment on the exploratory time (F (4.90) = 31.38, p < 0.0001) ( Figure 4B) and the preference percentages (F (4.45) = 3.99, p < 0.001) ( Figure 4C). Control group displayed a high preference to explore the N ( p < 0.01), whereas Sco-treated group exhibited a high preference ( p < 0.01) to explore F rather than to explore N, indicating memory impairment ( Figure 4B) The Sco-treated zebrafish subjected to either 150 µL/L and 300 µL/L of TEO showed a significantly higher preference for the N instead of F, suggesting memory improvement profile ( Figure 4B). Animals treated with Sco showed fewer percentages of preference ( p < 0.001) ( Figure 4C), as compared with the control group, whereas administration of TEO in the Sco-treated fish improved the percent of preferences for the N ( p < 0.01 for the 25, 150, and 300 μL/L), suggesting a memory-enhancing profile. Furheremore, the preference percentage in control (t = 29.15, p < 0.0001), Sco (t = 23.22, p < 0.0001), TEO (25 µL/L) + Sco (t = 18.42, p < 0.0001), TEO (150 µL/L) + Sco (t = 19.64, p < 0.0001), and TEO (300 µL/L) + Sco (t = 27.90, p < 0.0001) groups were statistically different from the chance level (50%) ( Figure 4C).
